bug.short_desc: AddFontResourceEx missing for ANSI in OS

long_desc.thetext:
According to MSDN, AddFontResourceEx is implemented as both Unicode and ANSI. However, it is unsupported in Windows 95/98/Me, only included in Windows 2000 and later. The older AddFontResource is implemented as both Unicode and ANSI. We currently implement AddFontResourceExW.
Also, RemoveFontResourceExA is not implemented.

bug.short_desc: Plugin's View Filter counter doesn't update upon target platform change

long_desc.thetext:
In the plug-ins view, there is a counter stating how many plug-ins the filter is currently matching. This number does not get updated upon selecting a new target platform.
Should be an easy fix. Need to listen for model changes in PluginsView instead of PluginsContentProvider. When models change, then need to refresh the viewer through the PluginsContentProvider, but also update the counter (updateContentDescription).
Assigning to Sean. Let's see what he is made of ;)

hooray for more help!

http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/IRC

come on Sean, you can do it ;)

Last day to get this fix in is Feb 2, 2007.
wake up, Sean :)

Created an attachment (id=57428) Here is the fix.
I must have taken to long to start work on this, there were some pretty big changes to PluginView and PluginContentProvider between when I first got the source and this patch ... of course the patch was really trivial now. I didn't realize such (seemingly) big changes would be made ... I mean PluginContentProvider no longer implements IPluginModelListener and PluginView does. Anyway, that looks like the right thing to do ... I just never would have done it since I'd have been afraid to break something else.

Thanks Sean. I just applied the patch, which plays very well. This patch is so much better than my good friend Chris' first patch :)
Your observations are all correct in comment 7 about the view and the listener. That is why I made the view to be the listener over the weekend.

bug.short_desc: [hashcode/equals] Suggestion for shorter Equals

long_desc.thetext: Moving to JDT/UI

You can make it even shorter than that using a collection of 'and' combinators:
AnyClass other = (obj instanceof AnyClass ? (AnyClass)obj : null ); return this == obj || ( obj != null && getClass() == obj.getClass() && !(this.field1 == null ? other.field1 == null : this.field1(equals(other.field1)) && !(this.field2 == null ? other.field2 == null : this.field2(equals(other.field2)) && );
i'm not sure how either the formatter would handle this, or the average programmer reading it, either. It would also be interesting to see (from a compiled approach) which one is better, or whether it makes any significant difference..
Alex.

bug.short_desc: [launcher] Console not working on Win32

long_desc.thetext:
The attached patch adds a console for the equinox launcher on win32.
However, it is not working with 1.4 VMs. The Java stdout, stdin, and stderr stream do not seem to be properly connected to the console.
This seems to be the problem described here: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4994125
Which implies the problem may come from mixing C runtime models. However, as far as I can tell, we are linking dynamically with MSVCRT.dll as we should be.
Created an attachment (id=55346) patch to add console

I'm not sure if this is related but we have issues when connecting to the input/output streams from the debug console when launching from eclipse also. See bug 40066. We implement a workaround in the console when osgi.dev=<anything> or when osgi.console.blockOnReady=true

Increase severity as I always use console to see debug trace. It's definitely necessary to have some information when a problem occurs while running an eclipse runtime session (in fact same severity than bug 168726...)

Note: AttachConsole is only in XP and greater so if W2K is to be supported as I assume then the entry point will have to be gotten conditionally through GetProcAddress and W2K will not work the same as XP and above.

Is 'Incubator' really the right component for this bug? I see this regression in normal SDK drops, so I guess the bug should be moved to 'Framework' (and get a Target Milestone of M6 or at least 3.3).
Yes, it should be moved to the framework component since the launcher work has been graduated from the incubator. Thanks, Markus.
*** Bug 178353 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Changing summary to be consistent with other [launcher] bugs.

The launcher was modified to use AttachConsole if possible (bug 173962 Comment #7). However, problems still exist here. Notably, with reusing the existing console, we should be able to redirect the output (eclipse -debug > out.txt), but this isn't working.

An additional annoyance with using AttachConsole I now see is that the console advances to the next command prompt and doesn't wait for eclipse.exe to terminate. The console output from eclipse.exe does go to the console but it's not synchronized with the invocation of eclipse.exe. As a part of that, other console commands can be executed generating output while eclipse is running that will be mixed with the eclipse output.
Here's and old discussion of getting output from a Win32 GUI application to the console I just found. http://blogs.msdn.com/junfeng/archive/2004/02/06/68531.aspx It identifies approaches used in two Microsoft tools.
The first approach, used by MS Visual Studio 2005 (and maybe 2003) in devenv.com/.exe, seems the more interesting of the two. It's a variation of the approach previously mentioned to have a full console and non-console version of eclipse.exe. The approach instead uses a small console application .exe renamed as a .com file. The small shim application invokes the full eclipse.exe, in the eclipse case, with the redirected handles etc. The application in the .com program is a true console application so the command prompt doesn't return until the .com and by implementation of the .com the launched .exe have exited.
The little trick that comes into play to make magic appear to happen is that on the commandline typing just "Eclipse" will invoke "Eclipse.com" if it exists instead of "Eclipse.exe". Even if the .com trick isn't used and a EclipseC.exe, or such, is created to launch the regular Eclipse.exe the technique is the best I've seen so far.
It seems like this would be W2K compatible as the AttachConsole would be gone from the full eclipse.exe. The AllocConsole in the .exe could still remain for cases that the .exe was invoked for console output but the .exe wasn't launched by the .com shim.
I'll look more into the DevEnv.com concept and come up with sample code. The sample could be pretty general and work with any .exe in the same directory by renaming the .com to to the name of the .exe to be launch. It seems like it would be best if the eclipse version also added a commandline parameter to the .exe parameters to indicate to the .exe that the console is hooked up or maybe there is a way that the .exe can detect that the console is already attached.
I'll see what I can come up with. The shim seems like it will meet all the "requirements" and be version independent of the .exe it's launching.
The second, used by ildasm doesn't seem usable because it puts up a console window on every launch. The console is quickly removed if it's not going to be used. It's not a good solution in my option.
PS: I can't actually build the Eclipse.exe in my development environment(s). With MSVS 6 makefile I have to hide later versions of the MSVS to get the PDK setenv to point to MSVS 6. I haven't been able to get the MinGW build environment to be setup right so it will do a complete build.

Starting in I20070430-0800, we now have an eclipsec.exe which is a console linked version of the launcher.
Changes for comment 10 were reverted. We decided against naming the console version eclipse.com because it was a little too much magic.

bug.short_desc: Removing calls to isStatic

long_desc.thetext:
Before the the patch:
PDOMFastReindex ExeTest (1 sources, 121 headers) PDOMFastReindex Timings: 1768891 total, 47907 parser, 3281 resolution, 1717422 index update. PDOMFastReindex Result: 44402 declarations, 40190 references, 0 errors, 3778 problems.
After the patch:
DOMFastReindex ExeTest (1 sources, 121 headers) PDOMFastReindex Timings: 212953 total, 48859 parser, 3281 resolution, 160406 index update. PDOMFastReindex Result: 44402 declarations, 40190 references, 0 errors, 3778 problems. PDOM Indexer Job Time: 212953
Almost an order of magnitude reduction. We really need to find out what is happening in isStatic before we put this back.

Created an attachment (id=55347) Reverse patch
Reverse this patch to put the calls to isStatic back.
BTW, these numbers are from the Windows SDK with the trilogy. There might be something peculiar in there making this problem worse, but I would be surprised. Mind you I've been surprised before.

Boy do I feel dumb. It turns out I had turned off the JIT in my test environment, which explains the ballooned numbers.
Now, with the JIT turned on, I am getting the trilogy in 13.5 seconds, right on target!
But with the isStatics put back, I'm still at over 3 minutes so the issue still stands.

I've mentioned this before, but in case you missed it, I'll just point out the existence of the ICPPInternalFunction.isStatic(boolean resolveAll). Binding resolution usually uses this and passes false. This was introduced for exactly the same kind of performance considerations.
O.K., I've switched to using the isStatic(false) methods and performance is good. Although this is only working for C++ functions since there is no equivalent for C functions.
I probably never added one for C since function resolution in C does not depend on that information.
Setting to milestone 4.0 so we can generate a report of all bugs fixed in 4.0.

bug.short_desc: items reported in Problem View can't be filtered

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061113
Steps To Reproduce: 1. clean a large project that has mixed php and html files, and contains both php and html validation/syntax problems 2. attempt to apply filter on view so that only PHP errors/warnings are listed
More information: PHPIDE reports all detected issues as "Problems" rather than something more specific (i.e. 'PHP Parser Problem') , which makes it impossible to apply a useful filter on the problem view.
it would be great to allow for more configuration options around the problem reporting.
PHPEclipse does this better in the following ways: 1. All of its errors are reported as the type "PHP Problem", which allows you to filter based on that criteria alone. 2. It recognizes things like uninitialized variables, mixed case constant declarations, and missing include files. 3. Each problems can be flagged as error, warning, or ignore.
PHPIDE could go even further, the configuration options around this one feature for the java compiler are too numerous to summarize. I think this kind of functionality would be a great extension of something that has the potential to easily become the number one IDE for PHP development.
Added a PHP category. Currently all PHP errors are of type : PHP Syntax Error.
fixed

bug.short_desc: File System Target Provisioner wizard glitches

long_desc.thetext:
The File system provisioner wizard is great.
It does have a few glitches though:
1a. Too many levels of indirection before choosing a directory. The Add Location dialog is not necessary. the Add... in the wizard should directly invoke the directory chooser.
Also, the Variables thing is a little weird here. I suspect you wanted to reuse the location dialog from the target editor. While it makes perfect sense for variables to appear in the target editor since those .target files are sharable. Here people just want to add directories and they are not sharing that info.
1b. The Edit... button should be removed when 1a is done.
2. The Directory choooser has amnesia. Every time I open it, it goes back to an all-collapsed uninitialized state. The first time it is open, we should initialize it to the current location of the target platform. Every subsequent time it is open, it should be initialized to the last location entered.
3. The help button in the bottom left does nothing. you need to hook up context help.
4. The wizard page description should read 'Add plug-ins from the file system to the target platform'
5. The font in the table viewer and label does not honor the dialog font preferences.
Created an attachment (id=55351) font problem
Assigning to Bauman.
Done. Will be in 3.3M4

bug.short_desc: Tracking of Number of Opened Connections may be incorrect

long_desc.thetext: The ODA consumer helper provides the service to track the number of opened connections to support the maximum limit allowed by individual ODA driver. This is done based on an ODA consumer's call to open and close a driver's connection. Such tracking however may become incorrect if an ODA consumer calls close on a connection before one is open.
Resolved
Verified and closed.

bug.short_desc: Derby plugin problem with webstart (packaging issue)

long_desc.thetext:
There is a problem with the current packaging of the derby plugin that prevents derby classes from being found by the classloader when running an RCP application using java webstart.
I rebuilt this plugin using a MANIFEST.MF that exports all the packages and specifies the classpath and it works.
You can find my packaging here (SVN Web access) http://sharemedia.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/sharemedia/org.apache.derby.core/

Hey Larry,
Can you take a look at this? I'd like to have this fixed for 1.0 if possible. Let me know.
Thanks in advance, Rob

This looks like a defect that has been fixed in Eclipse 3.2.1 by the Eclipse Equinox team. Please see defect https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149754. The original Derby defect is at http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DERBY-1446. If this is not the problem you are experiencing, please provide a detailed repro scenario.

This problem is only a packaging issue, there is no need to do code changes.
Scenario : 1 - Create a new RCP product (plugin/feature/product) 2 - Make the plugin depends on derby.core. 3 - Add Class.forName( "org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver").newInstance(); in the code 4 - Launch the product : I works. 5 - Export the feature for webstart 6 - Create a new feature for webstart, include & sign startup.jar, create the main jnlp, include the previous feature. 7 - Export the 2nd feature for webstart 8 - Launch the feature using the jnlp file. -> Class not found
Cause : In the derby plugin, the packages are exported using the plugin.xml. This does not work with webstart. This can de fixed by adding a manifest.mf and exporting the derby packages in this file :
Export-Package: org.apache.derby.authentication, org.apache.derby.catalog, org.apache.derby.catalog.types, org.apache.derby.client, org.apache.derby.client.am, org.apache.derby.client.net, bug.short_desc: [EditPart] Better support for rotation

long_desc.thetext: The current support for rotation by means of RotatableShapeEditPolicy and RotateShapeRequest is weak, as a RotateShapeRequest only tells if an object should be rotated, but not in what direction or how much. I have implemented support for rotation through the 8 main directions defined in PositionConstants. I.e. my RotateShapeRequest (and RotatableShapeEditPolicy) replacement tells in which direction a rotate gesture (using a rotation handle) started and ended (and can compute the difference. A granularity of 8 directions was chosen, as the constants are natural to work with and it's fairly easy for the user to target. I've chosen to update RotateTracker to provide cursor feedback (the various size cursors) during a drag, since the rectangle feedback does not indicate the current direction.

Created an attachment (id=55352) A replacement for RotatableShapeEditPolicy
This replacement for RotatableShapeEditPolicy supports finer granularity by computing the current rotation (one of the PositionContants) for the current position. It requires updated RotateShapeRequest and RotateTracker classes (other attachments). Note that these files have an Ex suffix, but should work as drop-in replacements (I had problems using the same names as the originals).

Created an attachment (id=55353) A replacement for RotateTracker
This replacement for RotateTracker provides better feedback during a rotate drag, by selecting a size cursor for the current rotation direction.

Created an attachment (id=55354) A replacement for RotateShapeRequest
Support for the final rotation direction of a drag, in addition to the existing starting drag (based on direction of the handle). This lets other edit policies create commands based on either absolute or relative rotation.

http://www.eclipse.org/proposals/linux-distro/
An ant script would be good enough?

(In reply to comment #1) > An ant script would be good enough? >
Everything that is needed to build an identical jar to http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-3.2.1-200609210945/download.php?dropFile=ecj.jar
Probably this just means the build.xml file.

The source.zip is intended to be attached to the binary.jar for browsing purpose. I am not sure the sources should be polluted with build files... at least, this would be a new requirement.
Shouldn't such a file rather be located elsewhere ? Could be linked from our development resources page... now I could see why bundling it would allow to evolve it along with the sources layout.

(In reply to comment #3) > The source.zip is intended to be attached to the binary.jar for browsing > purpose. I am not sure the sources should be polluted with build files... at > least, this would be a new requirement. >
This is exactly the attitude that makes Eclipse so hard to package on Linux distributions and what the linux-distro project tries to solve. One build.xml file is hardly much pollution and for example on Gentoo our package manager automatically creates the src.zip stripped to just java files if you want to.
> > Shouldn't such a file rather be located elsewhere ? Could be linked from our > development resources page... now I could see why bundling it would allow to > evolve it along with the sources layout. >
Just makes things unnecessarily harder. Hopefully this does not come out as too harsh. If you want to have a separate stripped src.zip that is fine by me. It should not be hard to write ant targets to automatically create the files for you.
Thanks.
Released for 3.3M6. I'll verify the next build to see if the script is properly included.
Verified for 3.3 M6 using build I20070321-0010

bug.short_desc: error in ecore or in XMI?

long_desc.thetext:
I was using the openarchitectureware to create an ecore model as psdsl.ecore:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ASCII"?> <ecore:EPackage xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:ecore="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore" name="pfdsl" nsURI="http://uk.ac.open/pf" nsPrefix="pfdsl"> <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="ProblemDiagram"> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/> </eClassifiers> </ecore:EPackage>
When I use the "dynamic object" generation in the "Self reflective ecore editor", a simple EMF model is saved as the following XMI. (Note I entered one attribute "name" in the ecore editor before I save it. Otherwise, the default one does not present the error described below.)
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ASCII"?> <pfdsl:ProblemDiagram xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:pfdsl="http://uk.ac.open/pf" name="example"/>
I can open this file in the XMI editor without problem.
Then I used the above Ecore metamodel to generate the editor plugins such that I could open the same XMI file into the generated EMF editor. However, the following exception is fired when the file is being loaded:
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl$1$DiagnosticWrappedException: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.FeatureNotFoundException: Feature 'name' not found. (platform:/resource/Examples/pf/out.pfdsl, 2, 127) at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.handleDemandLoadException(ResourceSetImpl.java:307) at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.demandLoadHelper(ResourceSetImpl.java:268) at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.getResource(ResourceSetImpl.java:390) at pfdsl.presentation.PfdslEditor.createModel(PfdslEditor.java:906) at pfdsl.presentation.PfdslEditor.createPages(PfdslEditor.java:962) at org.eclipse.ui.part.MultiPageEditorPart.createPartControl(MultiPageEditorPart.java:276) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorReference.createPartHelper(EditorReference.java:596) ...
Another hint for the error is, when I try to open the XMI document through the API, it reports the following exception:
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.EFactoryImpl at pfdsl.impl.PfdslFactoryImpl.init(PfdslFactoryImpl.java:34) at pfdsl.PfdslFactory.<clinit>(PfdslFactory.java:26) at pfdsl.impl.PfdslPackageImpl.<init>(PfdslPackageImpl.java:49) at pfdsl.impl.PfdslPackageImpl.init(PfdslPackageImpl.java:85) at pfdsl.PfdslPackage.<clinit>(PfdslPackage.java:59) at my.parse.save_model(parse.java:77) at my.parse.main(parse.java:38)
the problematic statement is the initialization for the PfdslPackage.eINSTANCE:
77 resourceSet.getPackageRegistry().put( PfdslPackage.eNS_URI, PfdslPackage.eINSTANCE);
I am wondering whether the Ecore model generated from the openarchitectureware is incorrect, or the EMF code generation is incorrect.

I can't reproduce any problems using this model. It happily reads and writes instances of this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <pfdsl:ProblemDiagram xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:pfdsl="http://uk.ac.open/pf" name="fasdfasdf"/>
It sounds like you have more of an installation problem. You need to track down what's going wrong with the intialization of the package and factory...
Confirmed, after I reinstalled everything and curiously the problem is gone ! Thank you for the help.

bug.short_desc: [IRC] Users parting does not get picked up by channels

long_desc.thetext: When a user leaves a channel via the PART message and not the QUIT message. No notifications are sent out to listeners.

Created an attachment (id=55357) Project-level patch to fix the problem.
This fires the presence listeners accordingly and also performs a fix for a synchronized block for onPing(String). 'this' is referring to the listener when it should be referring to the IRCRootContainer "outer class".
Patch applied and ip log updated. Thanks Remy.

attachment.desc: Project-level patch to fix the problem.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers]Open AbstractTreeViewer for external widget implementors

long_desc.thetext: As reported by Ross Camara AbstractTreeViewer would work for nebula if we would open the API a bit. Boris and I decided that we will do this in 2 steps: 1. open the API 2. moving the Virtual-Support bits from TreeViewer to AbstractTreeViewer when the nebula grid provides virtual support.

Created an attachment (id=55569) A patch to start discussion
I know Boris and I have thought about opening AbstractTreeViewer but after playing around a bit i think the better idea is to take the same approach like we did for TableViewer, so I started and finally it was not really a lot of work. The only thing discussable is the name of the new Viewer called VirtualAbstractTreeViewer, I think we should come up with an equal name for both of our widget-independent-columnbased-viewers.

Created an attachment (id=56189) Open AbstractTreeViewer as much as need for subclassers
Ok guys this time a patch which opens AbstractTreeViewer and moves common things from TreeViewer to it so that subclassers can easily implement a viewer on top of it.
I've also included a potential implementation for Grid and a test snippet which is copied from our snippets collection. Please report back as soon as possible whether the API provided using this patch is open enough to all of you.

One comment i had when implementing the GridViewers is that in both implementations i needed to override the getViewerRowFromItem(Widget) method. The problem here is that if we don't find the viewer row in the data map of the widget we return null throwing an NPE. In the TreeViewer you override the method also so that when no ViewerRow is found we create a new ViewerRow to return. I think we should just make this method abstract and not provide the base implementation.

(In reply to comment #3) > One comment i had when implementing the GridViewers is that in both > implementations i needed to override the getViewerRowFromItem(Widget) method. > The problem here is that if we don't find the viewer row in the data map of the > widget we return null throwing an NPE. In the TreeViewer you override the > method also so that when no ViewerRow is found we create a new ViewerRow to > return. I think we should just make this method abstract and not provide the > base implementation. >
well this is not possible because if we declare this method abstract in AbstractTreeViewer we would break API contracts backwards. We can declare it abstract of course in ColumnViewer and AbstractTableViewer we can do that and it would certainly make sense IMHO. That's why I once proposed to insert a new Sub-Class below AbstractTreeViewer which declares the method as abstract which could not be declared abstract in AbstractTreeViewer because of backwards compatility. E.g. getItemAt() is also such a method!
Created an attachment (id=56880) Reapply able to head

Slighlty modified patch released >20070117. Chris, can you please have a look at HEAD to make sure I didn't break your subclasses? I made two methods final that were previously not.
For 3.3, we don't have enough time to address the SWT.VIRTUAL case, this will have to wait and should be tracked with a new bug.
Verified with the latest version of cvs and our viewers still work.
Tom, Boris - thanks for all the hard work.

attachment.desc: Open AbstractTreeViewer as much as need for subclassers

bug.short_desc: no completions available for methods

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2 and 3.2.1
Steps To Reproduce: 1.created a new java projet 2.created a new class in the java project 3.wrote System. (for example) and didn't get the auto completion
More information: the import auto completion works (example import java. shows awt etc etc) the method's parameters auto completion works (example new Integer( shows parameter 1 etc etc) but methods for a class instance do not work (I tried jdk 1.5 and jdk 1.4 and the problem remains for both)
the error was mine, it wasn't a bug

bug.short_desc: [Viewers]ViewerCell and ViewerRow should provide API to find neighbors

long_desc.thetext:
This is a very important feature if we want provide keyboard features in tables and trees and the current EditingSupport has TODO items to make this work in a clear way. I'd propose the following new API functions for ViewerCell: - ViewerCell#getCellLeft() - ViewerCell#getCellRight() - ViewerCell#getCellTop() - ViewerCell#getCellBottom() - ViewerRow#getRowTop() - ViewerRow#getRowBottom()
What I'm not 100% sure is if we should provide functions to navigate Tree-Structures: - ViewerCell#getCellTop(boolean samelevel) - ViewerCell#getCellBottom(boolean samelevel) - ViewerRow#getRowTop(boolean samelevel) - ViewerRow#getRowBottom(boolean samelevel)

Created an attachment (id=55449) I banged my head against it now for a while but finally it's working ;-)
Support for Tables is really easy but the one for trees really really took sometime and I hope I have successfully identified all cases.

+1 but I would like us to use just one method per class together with constants for the direction:
ViewerCell.getNeighbor(int direction)
where direction can be one of ViewerCell.ABOVE ViewerCell.BELOW ViewerCell.LEFT ViewerCell.RIGHT

Created an attachment (id=55916) Addressing Boris requestes
This addresses Boris concerns, fixes internals to speed up the Tree-search, fixes small bugs and provides access cell e.g. in the upper-left of the current cell using BITMASKs. You can give it a try using the snippet contained in the patch:
- TAB to travers horizontal right (at the end jump to the next row) - SHIFT+TAB to travers horizontal left (at the begining jump to the above row) - CTRL+TAB to travers vertically to the next row - CTRL+SHIFT+TAB tor travers vertically to the above row
When I think about the names wouldn't it make sense to use: - NORTH - SOUTH - EAST - WEST instead?
Created an attachment (id=56191) Apply to HEAD cleanly
cc'ing chris because this is something Nebula has to implement
Created an attachment (id=57078) Extracted from Mega-Patch in151295
Patch with improved Javadoc released >20070120. See bug 171126 for outstanding issues with the implementation.

attachment.desc: I banged my head against it now for a while but finally it's working ;-)

More information: Command-left and -right arrow work, but I have picked up the Home/Edit habit from daily use in Windows Eclipse. I'd like to be able to use Home/Edit at home, too.

bug.short_desc: http request tracing tool for all repository connectors

long_desc.thetext: Provide http request tracing tool for all repository connectors (perhaps available on repository prefs page next to Validate button). So, it could show request details similar to "wget -v -d ..." and would also allow to save returned document to file. That would help to debug connection as well as parsing issues for all connectors.

I feel a urgent need for this thing to debug what the web connector is doing.
When I tried to configure it to work with the mantis repository, it was a pain in the a$$ to try to figure out what was happening, what URLs it was trying to access, if there is a error on the pattern or it is because it is returning a error page, etc...
I had to debug the connector, put some breakpoints, examine the httpclient variables, until discover it was a bug on connector.
Regarding you idea, Eugene, I'd like to suggest to create a "Mylar Console", similar to the "CVS console", where the user can track all operations the connectors are trying to do.

(In reply to comment #1) > I feel a urgent need for this thing to debug what the web connector is doing. > > When I tried to configure it to work with the mantis repository, it was a pain > in the a$$ to try to figure out what was happening, what URLs it was trying to > access, if there is a error on the pattern or it is because it is returning a > error page, etc...
I was going to check if I can add a link to the error message, that would open external web browser with content fetched from the current url.
> I had to debug the connector, put some breakpoints, examine the httpclient > variables, until discover it was a bug on connector.
Generally I just use wget to track down all the redirects and locations.
> Regarding you idea, Eugene, I'd like to suggest to create a "Mylar Console", > similar to the "CVS console", where the user can track all operations the > connectors are trying to do.
Not sure if console will work. We need to debug this stuff while being in the modal dialogs (repository properties or query wizard). So, I guess only practical options are either another popup dialog, or separate wizard page.

(In reply to comment #2) > Generally I just use wget to track down all the redirects and locations.
The idea is to avoid using external tools (at least for the major cases).
> Not sure if console will work. We need to debug this stuff while being in the > modal dialogs (repository properties or query wizard). So, I guess only > practical options are either another popup dialog, or separate wizard page. >
Yes, the console would be for general connector tracking. For the webconnector we can have a little expandable section on the wizard, like what exists today for templates, with a panel where we can track the communication when the user hits "Preview".
With this, we can at least see what URLs are being called, and the contents that are being returned. This should help a lot.

(In reply to comment #3) > (In reply to comment #2) > > Generally I just use wget to track down all the redirects and locations. > The idea is to avoid using external tools (at least for the major cases).
I know. It was my idea after all. I just saying that you could of used the right tools. :-)
> > Not sure if console will work. We need to debug this stuff while being in the > > modal dialogs (repository properties or query wizard). So, I guess only > > practical options are either another popup dialog, or separate wizard page. > Yes, the console would be for general connector tracking.
Not sure it is needed after we already verified connection.
> For the webconnector > we can have a little expandable section on the wizard, like what exists today > for templates, with a panel where we can track the communication when the user > hits "Preview".
Heh. There is already too many expandable areas. This approach to UI does not scale well.
> With this, we can at least see what URLs are being called, and the contents > that are being returned. This should help a lot.
Url and content will be possible to see from the link in the error message. We don't need console for that.
What console is really needed for is to see response headers and redirects...

(In reply to comment #4) > I know. It was my idea after all. I just saying that you could of used the > right tools. :-)
Yes, I was completely unaware of wget. I'll start to use it next time.
> Heh. There is already too many expandable areas. This approach to UI does not > scale well.
:-)
> Url and content will be possible to see from the link in the error message. We > don't need console for that. > > What console is really needed for is to see response headers and redirects... >
I need to see the complete redirect story, not only the last URL.

(In reply to comment #5) > > What console is really needed for is to see response headers and redirects... > I need to see the complete redirect story, not only the last URL.
That is what you'll see in the trace.

bug.short_desc: visual indication for task attributes changed locally

long_desc.thetext: Task editor now shows attributes updated in recent synchronizations. The similar indication (using different color) should be done for attributes changed locally and not yet sent to the server.
Very good idea. We can try to use (not sure how...) the same colors used on synchronization: blue/black/red for incoming/outgoing/conflict.

I actually already using red for incoming changes, because it is easier to notice then default color. So, yellow should work well for outgoing changes.
Not sure about conflicts though. Those aren't shown in the editor and it is unclear how conflict resolution is going to work. Right now it is just overwriting everything except comments.

bug.short_desc: [preferences] allow default estimated time to be set for local tasks

long_desc.thetext:
New task editor is using one hour as an estimated time for newly created tasks. This is very uncommon and default should set to 0.
Also, width of the spinner box is too large for these values.

This was done deliberately in order to make estimation come for free without the user needing to always remember to estimate each task, just to adjust down to 0 for some tasks, and higher than 1 for others. In other words, to make the XP-style planning practice Kent Beck advocates easy. That said, there is no single right answer for this so we almost certainly need a preference setting. Marking P2 for now because post-1.0 the planning support needs to be come more configurable.

I would agree that it is always makes sense for local tasks, but very unlikely needed for repository tasks. However that timing could screw up your non-disableable never green bar, if those new repository tasks scheduled for reasons other then working on them (i.e. reminder for a follow up)...

More precisely it doesn't make sense for repository tasks that you create for others, but does make sense for repository tasks that you create for yourself. We still need to support both modes, and perhaps there are cases where we detect. For example, "Report as Bug" in the Error Log should clearly not schedule for today. However, even in this case scheduling can still make sense. For example, I schedule each bug report that I report to Eclipse for 2 weeks later so that I follow up on it. One thing we could do to make the UI easier is have a radio chooser along these lines.
Schedule for: [never] [today] [next week] [two weeks] [custom date [pick...]]

Mik, I would say that most of the repository bugs are not created for "yourself".
What we can do there is to allow to specify tentative assignment for created bug (even server does not allow that you could make second call to reassign issue to yourself after it is created). Default choice would rely on server side logic, but you can choose to assign it to youself (we can make editor to remember last choice), then estimate could be set to default.
Please don't use radio buttons for scheduling it will eat up lots of screen space. I think current selection is optimal. It is compact and most of the time I am using Clear on it (and suspect that most users should do the same when filling bugs for others). Though that date drop down could show the same menu as in task list, and have actual data selection dialog as one of the options in that menu.

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] Update Naming Conventions for test class names

long_desc.thetext:
The naming conventions[1] page on the wiki states...
"For class Xyz, the test class name should be TestXyz"
Most projects don't follow this convention and instead name their tests XyzTest. I'm not sure of the process to go about for changing this, nor the team to log it to, but it would be nice to clean up this up.
[1] http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Naming_Conventions#Test_Suite_Packages
We won't have time to work on this in the forseeable future.

I should probably be more specific. I was wanting to update the naming conventions on the wiki, not update any code. I would change the wiki myself but I wasn't sure if there was a process for changing guidelines.
Martin may have a stronger opinion than me on whether you should make this change or not
I agree with the bug request, we also use XyzTest. I don't know if other teams use other conventions. Why not mention both? Who is the author of the naming convention document? Denis, do you know?

(In reply to comment #4) > Who is the author of the naming convention document? Denis, do you know? >
The document was originally authored in 2001 and hadn't been maintained as it was in an obscure place on our site. I'm guessing someone on the Eclipse project authored it back in the day.
> I don't know if other teams > use other conventions. Why not mention both?
This would be a great question for the cross-project-issues-dev list.

Reopening as it seems that there are some things to discuss.
(In reply to comment #4) > I agree with the bug request, we also use XyzTest. I don't know if other teams > use other conventions. Why not mention both?
Personally I would just list one. It's only a recommendation and anyone could choose to go another route without any ramifications. Too many recommendations just muddies the waters in my opinion.

(In reply to comment #5) > > I don't know if other teams > > use other conventions. Why not mention both? > > This would be a great question for the cross-project-issues-dev list. >
I messed up the initial email but this has been posted to the cross-project-issues-dev list[1].
[1] http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cross-project-issues-dev/msg01282.html

Well ... it is a community wiki ... have at it! :)
Or, you seem the conservative type, so better advice would be ... I don't think anyone would mind if you make small notes that said, basically, "in our XYZ project, we use the convention ABC", and provide a link to your own projects conventions wiki page.
In WTP we did not provide that tie-in, but we do document our own WTP conventions http://www.eclipse.org/webtools/development/guidelines/naming-conventions.html where we disagree or depart from the "standard" conventions.
And, FYI, there are also some very similar conventions documented as part of Eclipse Help. http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/naming.html
I'm sure not everyone will agree on all conventions, but I don't think that's needed for Eclipse as a whole ... and hard enough to do within one project. But, I think it does help to document patterns that you've found good and useful, then others looking for guidance can pick the ones that make the most sense to them. And the bad ones will eventually die out :)

The section about TestXyz was added in the wiki by an anonymous contributor. The general convention in JUnit is XyzTest, which is also what the New JUnit Test Case wizard does when started while a type is selected.
I've fixed the wiki according to comment 0.

I have just removed the three extra rules added by the wiki contributor. These are the Eclipse top-level project's naming conventions, and it's not the place of someone in the community to add extra rules to our naming conventions without consensus from the committers on the project.

(In reply to comment #11)
Perhaps the page should be moved to Eclipse Project Naming Conventions to avoid confusion?

(In reply to comment #12) > (In reply to comment #11) > > Perhaps the page should be moved to Eclipse Project Naming Conventions to avoid > confusion? >
+1
Also is there anyone monitoring changes to these pages? The openness of the wiki is great but for conventions and guidelines that need to be approved this can be a source of confusion when someone makes these sort of changes.

bug.short_desc: New local task is being added to arbitrary category and is non-movable?

long_desc.thetext: when I add a new local task, the new local task is always being added to a certain of my (non-query) categories as well as appearing at the root of the task list. When I try to move the task out of the category (using the move sub-menu) from the category into which it placed it, it will not move (no error message, etc.). When I move the root-level version it moves but the other "instance" of it remains in the category. I cannot delete these new local tasks from within the (incorrect) category.

I can not reproduce this and tried the following * Creating a new local task with nothing selected in Task List: adds to root * Creating a new local task with category selected adds it to the category * Moves work via drag-and-drop and context menu, deletes work
So it sounds like either you had something in the "Find: " filter, or there is a serious configuration problem. Could you check your configuration to make sure that you have only Mylar 1.0.0 installed, and reopen the bug if you can still reproduce?

bug.short_desc: [discussion] Split web connector templates into a different plugin

long_desc.thetext:
The web connector has a lot of templates (ok, only 11 right now). Maybe it should be possible to use the web connector without all the templates for the various open source projects?
I am planning for suggesting using Mylar to some of our non-programmers, such as analysts and testers (but I haven't actually tried yet how well Mylar works with the products they use -- most likely even won't work with the current versions such as Rational Functional Tester 6.0 -- so this is most likely not going to happen right now, but maybe soon). I'll probably also provide a custom Changelogic template for them so they wouldn't have to change any parameters, except maybe their project_id parameter to the query.
All the current open source repository templates are of no interest to them and it would be nice if they wouldn't see them at all. With Eclipse 3.3 I could probably solve this with the new product customization / XSLT features, but I think we will be stuck with 3.2-based products for quite some time even if we'd get there soon. And maybe Mylar could provide this separation from the start by having the templates in a separate plugin/feature called "Mylar Connector: Common Web Templates" or something like that. On the other hand, splitting the web connector this way could be somewhat confusing for other users, I think?

I struggle with this question too. I think that if you install the Task List alone as you suggest (e.g. http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_User_Guide#Rich_Task_List_Install) you should get no templates. So I think that we should move the tempaltes into org.eclipse.mylar.ide. Thoughts?

I considered moving them, but think it best to leave the templates where they are for 1.0.1 because we can not create a new plug-in, and moving them to mylar.ide would mean that people could not use the web connector without installing the Focused UI. But let's revisit this post 1.0.1.
Reassigning to inbox since it hasn't been decided upon.

We are experiencing library (runtime environment) problems with Apache axis 1.3 on the OHF bridge at this time that we believe are causing this issue.
Other bugs related to this issue are: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=164983
and: http://ihe.univ-rennes1.fr/flyspray/?do=details&id=97
We are working to resolve this bug immediately.
*** Bug 167309 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Done
closing

bug.short_desc: Creating a attachment does not refresh the editor

long_desc.thetext:
Mylar 1.0-test, Eclipse 3.3M3:
While creating a patch for bug#167282, I noticed the following:
- I was with the corresponding task activated and taskeditor opened. - I created the patch to clipboard, and attached to the bug. - I noticed that after submiting the patch the bug editor does not refreshed. - Then I tried to force a refresh (F5) directly on tasklist. I didn't work. - I closed the taskeditor and reopened. Only then the change was detected and the bug was refreshed.

I just tried to reproduce this failure both with a GIF attachment and with a clipboard attachment and could not--editor always reloaded after attachment. Perhaps this was due to the recent notorious bugs.eclipse.org hangs, which translate to timeouts for us?
Created an attachment (id=55390) test attachment
Created an attachment (id=55391) test 2
Created an attachment (id=55392) test 3
Created an attachment (id=55393) test 4

Humm... aparently it is working now. I just tested with Eclipse 3.1.2 at work.
If you want, you can mark WORKSFORME for now, and I can reopen if it happens again.
Done.

It happen again while after submitting the patch for bug#168248.
Exactly the same thing, but with Eclipse 3.3 M4 + Mylar dev-build.
Created an attachment (id=55810) test 5

I just discovered the steps to reproduce:
1 - Create a new bugzilla repository task. 2 - Activate the newly created task. 3 - Open any java class on your workspace, just to build some context. 4 - Deactivate the task. 5 - Activate it again. 6 - Open the task. 7 - Add a new attachment. 8 - Attach any text file (e.g. the tests attached to this bug), but ensure to mark the "patch" and "attach context" checkboxes. 9 - Finish.
After that, the editor won't reload. If you force a synchronize on task list, it won't either.
If you close the task and reopen it, the 2 attachments will appear.
Is this still relevant?
Editor now refreshes in place but interaction still needs improvement (bug#171135).

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt][Perspectives] Add edtiors' layout information to perspectiveExtensions' extensiton point

long_desc.thetext:
Actually, what I want is adding the published API to manage editors' layout(such as IDE.openEditor(IWorkbenchPage page, IFile input, String editorStackID)), and change the perspectiveExtensions' extension point to add the editors' layout information(such as different types of file have different stacks):
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.perspectiveExtensions"> <perspectiveExtension targetID="org.eclipse.ui.resourcePerspective"> <actionSet id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaActionSet"/> <viewShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.PackageExplorer"/> <newWizardShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.wizards.NewProjectCreationWizard"/> <perspectiveShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective"/> <view id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.PackageExplorer" relative="org.eclipse.ui.views.ResourceNavigator" relationship="stack"/> <view id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.TypeHierarchy" relative="org.eclipse.ui.views.ResourceNavigator" relationship="left" ratio="0.50"/> <!--add editor stack layout information just like view layout--> <editorStack id="DefaultEditorWorkbook"/><!-- this is the default workbook id--> <editorStack id="MyNewEditorStack" relative="DefaultEditorWorkbook" relationship="bottom" ratio="0.50"/>
</perspectiveExtension> </extension>
Then, in my applicaiton, I can call the IDE.openEditor(workbenchPage, file, "MyNewEditorStack") to open the editor and place it at right position. But, if many plug-ins have their own editorStack definitions, the editor area will be in a mess... Hmm, hope a best solution could be given, :) Thanks!
*** Bug 167338 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Mmm. Paul, do you have an opinion on this? This is more closely related to perspectives so I dont feel comfortable saying yay or nay on my own.

Maybe, it's not a good idea that editor layout information have relation to perspectives... But, it's useful if providing published API to manage the editors' layout, such as opening an editor at right position(stack), moving an editor to another position(stack)...

bug.short_desc: minor glitch in eclipse sdk feature suffix

long_desc.thetext:
Do you all like to collect cases where the suffix is computed in a non-monotonic way? Here's one for the eclipse.sdk feature.
3.2.1.r321_v20060801-tQ1w49KnTArT0FZ (3.2.1 release) 3.2.1.r321_v20060801-iy4CzlSkiFk_pNZ (11/29 version) 3.2.1.r321_v20060801-wy4D-BLij8Q1bPZ (12/5 version)
Seems all is fine now (12/5), but the 11/29 version "went down" from the released version. I suspect the feature should be changed to 3.2.2 at this point anyway ... but, thought I'd call it to your attention, since I have a faint memory of you all wanting to "see some cases".
Moving to PDE Build for comment since the qualifier calculation is done there.
Some bugs have been identified in the qualifier computation. See Bug 157049, bug 162020 and bug 162022.
Marking as M5, to test again those builds once we have released the patches provided by David Olsen.
This has been fixed.

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchLayout] Add editors' layout information to perspectiveExtensions' extension point

long_desc.thetext:
Actually, what I want is adding the published API to manage editors' layout(such as IDE.openEditor(IWorkbenchPage page, IFile input, String editorId, String editorStackId)), and change the perspectiveExtensions' extension point to add the editors' layout information(such as different types of file have different stacks):
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.perspectiveExtensions"> <perspectiveExtension targetID="org.eclipse.ui.resourcePerspective"> <actionSet id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaActionSet"/> <viewShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.PackageExplorer"/> <newWizardShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.wizards.NewProjectCreationWizard"/> <perspectiveShortcut id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaPerspective"/> <view id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.PackageExplorer" relative="org.eclipse.ui.views.ResourceNavigator" relationship="stack"/> <view id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.TypeHierarchy" relative="org.eclipse.ui.views.ResourceNavigator" relationship="left" ratio="0.50"/> <!--add editor stack layout information just like view layout--> <editorStack id="DefaultEditorWorkbook"/><!-- this is the default workbook id--> <editorStack id="MyNewEditorStack" relative="DefaultEditorWorkbook" relationship="bottom" ratio="0.50"/>
</perspectiveExtension> </extension>
Then, in my applicaiton, I can call IDE.openEditor(workbenchPage, file, editorId, "MyNewEditorStack") to open the editor and place it at right position. Thanks!
Sorry, this is duplicate of 167336. When I committing 167336, the bugzilla server encountered an internal problem, so I reported it again... This one can be deleted, thanks!
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 167336 ***

This will avoid polluting out bug list with duplicates, and is easy to do since the submitted bug will reopen if successfully submitted.

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] WorkbenchAdvisor#preShutdown() misses details about how the application was closed

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse 3.3. M3
preShutdown() should provide details about how the application was closed:
- QuitAction - Shell closed - ESC pressed
Usecase: A lot of applications provide an option to move the application to the system-tray when you hit the Close-Button on the Shell. However, as soon as the user performs the QuitAction, the application should really quit.
Ben
Ben please feel free to attach a suggested API as a patch. Bear in mind that M5 is the API freeze for 3.3.

It turns out WorkbenchWindowAdvisor#preWindowShellClose() is totally doing what I was looking for :)
Ben

bug.short_desc: CDT should use the Java code formater and rules

long_desc.thetext:
CDT should extend the Eclipse Java code formatter and use it as the native/default option. The Java formatter is very mature and extreamly usefully. The code syntax is very similar, so extending the current source base to support C++ code shouldn't be that difficult.
Code formating is very important part in development and having good coding standards are a key part in maintenance. Not having a good formatter for CDT is a problem. Eclipse already has a good, mature and very configurable code formatter for Java, and should be extended for usage with C/C++ code.
BTW: Using GNU Indent is not an option. Some people swear by it, but "indent" is based on a very poor and very "unprofessional" looking coding standard, that is hard to fix with the limited options provided by the tool. If this options are not used right, you may end up with uncompilable code (that previously worked) and violating your project's coding standards.

We are on the way. Community help wanted!

bug.short_desc: Permit auto-sync of repository tasks when commits made against them.

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse Build ID: M20060921-0945 Mylar version: 0.9.2.2
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Find a repository that has comments added to the bug when commits are made against the bug (e.g. Bugzilla with SCMbug) 2. Make commits against tasks from that repository. 3. Observe that you must manually refresh the task after committing.
Our installation of SCMbug forces committers to specify a valid bug number when committing changes to the source, and then it automatically mirrors the SVN commit message into a comment on the bug. It would be nice if Mylar had a setting wherein it would auto-sync the task when commits are made against that task -- currently, this must be done by hand to avoid clashes later.

I wonder if any other issue tracking system does that?
By the way, at some point I was suggesting to add feature to synchronize other way around. If issue tracking system received new comment, or even context attachment, then we know what projects has been changed, so only these projects need to be synchronized. Though I am not sure if there is an unified Team API for kicking synchronizations.

(In reply to comment #1) Perhaps my report was confusingly worded. I was not suggesting that we synchronise the project following a commit from someone else, but instead that we synchronise the task following a commit by me.

It was clear enough to me. However, personally I don't see much need to rush task synchronization for changes you already know about. Also, why synchronize only tasks you committed but not tasks you got in the incoming changes?
My comment was referring to separate but somehow related issue, when synchronizing many projects with version control is quite slow. That is why I reminded about that old idea for the opposite synchronization.

(In reply to comment #3) > It was clear enough to me. However, personally I don't see much need to rush > task synchronization for changes you already know about.
True, but it might be nice :-- hence my setting the priority to ENHANCEMENT :).

By the way, if we get into implementing this, it seem like a good idea to enable 3rd party plugins to add arbitrary attributes to the task repositories, then contribute own pages for editing these attributes (e.g. force task sync after commit) and also somehow notify those guys about commits and other activities. Then we'll have flexible infrastructure for implementing this kind of stuff.
Out of scope for 2.0 so marking helpwanted in case anyone is interested in contributing this.

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] Files opened with "File->Open File..." aren't persisted in recently used files list and/or restored in the workspace on application restart

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a new plugin project containing an editor 2. In the plugin manifest create a content type extension that extends the org.eclipse.core.runtime.xml base type, and uses the describer org.eclipse.core.runtime.content.XMLRootElementContentDescriber to determine that XML files with a particular top element belongs to the format 3. In the plugin manifest for the editor defined in 1. add a contentTypeBinding to the content type defined in 2. 4. Start an eclipse application containing the plugin 5. Select "File->Open File..." and open a file of the XML type described in 2. It should open in the editor in the plugin created in step 1. 6. Open the File menu and observe that the file is in the recently used files list 7. Stop the eclipse application and restart it 8. Observe that the file opened in the previous session isn't restored 9. Open the file menu and observe that the file is no longer in the recently used files list
More information: I'm aware that this is caused by OpenExternalFileAction creating a JavaFileEditorInput for files not in the workspace, and that things aren't persisted because the JavaFileEditorInput class isn't persistable.
I'm also aware that in some cases this will be the desired behaviour (it will be the desired behaviour for those used to the current behaviour).
However I still think that this is a bug, since _if_ one wants "File->Open File..." to behave the way I'd like to today, there is no way around it except for replacing it (which, unless I'm mistaken, means building up all system menus manually, using an ActionBarAdviser).
There's also the issue that someone (most maybe?) would like a persisted recently used file list, but not restored editors in the workspace, after a restart. And right now those two features are linked. Perhaps they should be split?

As a side note: I created a persistable IPathEditorInput class, and replaced the actual input in my editor's init() method. This succeeded in restoring opened editors on eclipse application restart, but did not successfully persist the recently used files list (which was what I _really_ wanted). And there was no way I was able to touch the internal EditorHistory object in the workbench, which keeps the association of editor inputs and editors.
That's something I fixed some time ago in Platform Text and then submitted to Platform UI as enhancement to their FileStoreEditorInput.
Verified in I20070322-1800

bug.short_desc: JSP does not respect TEI VariableInfo

long_desc.thetext:
I have upgraded to eclipse 3.2.1, WST 1.5.2.v200610070620 and JST 1.5.2.v200610070620, I am using struts 1.2.4 in a dynamic web application. However all the variables exposed by struts logic tags are marked as "cannot be resolved". I am on Win XP and JDK 1.5.0_08. However, the application itself is running wihout any error, only jsp validation is failing.
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #87143 +++
We have a tag TableTag with attributes "id" and "type", which are used to declare a variable within the body of the tag. So for example, the TableTei contains the following:
public class TableTei extends TagExtraInfo { public VariableInfo[] getVariableInfo(TagData data) { VariableInfo [] variables = new VariableInfo[1]; variables[0] = new VariableInfo(data.getAttributeString("id"), data.getAttributeString("type"), true, VariableInfo.NESTED); return variables; } }
Then the tag can be used like so:
<mca:table id="summary" type="com.mcasolutions.application.web.exceptionSummary.ExceptionSummary" ...> <% if (summary.isAlert()) { %> ... <% } %> </mca:table>
In the JSP editor, the following happens:
- The token "summary" is highlighted with a red squiggly. - If you mouseover the squiggly, you get a tooltip with the error: "summary cannot be resolved". - A red marker appears in the right-hand margin bar to signal an error. - No error appears in the Problems view pane. - No red-X marker appears in the left-hand margin bar.

Vasanth, is your struts.jar file directly under the workspace directory or external? My this I mean is the struts.jar or the project located outside of the workspace directory? Or possibly is the struts.jar file installed in your server runtime's or JRE's lib folder?

(In reply to comment #1) > Vasanth, is your struts.jar file directly under the workspace directory or > external? My this I mean is the struts.jar or the project located outside of > the workspace directory? Or possibly is the struts.jar file installed in your > server runtime's or JRE's lib folder?
The project itself is under an external directory. Eclipse workspace is at c:\Vasanth\eclipse-workspace, whereas the project is at c:\Vasanth\projects\mystrutsproject and struts.jar is at c:\vasanth\projects\mystrutsproject\develop\webroot\WEB-INF\struts.jar. Infact, all the jars used by the application are under WEB-INF folder. Other than JRE/JDK, everything else (all jars) are within the application - i.e., I dont have any other shared libs outside of the application.
Actually folders are c:\vasanth\projects\mystrutsproject\develop\webroot\WEB-INF\lib\struts.jar. My prev. comment has a typo.

Then it sounds like bug 178443, which regards missing TEI variables for a specific case, is really the same as this one. It's chronologically backwards, but I'm going to mark this one as the dupe.
